meta.title: COVID-19 FAQs - Enumclaw School District

body.class: fsLiveMode fsHasHeader fsHasLeftBanner fsHasMenu fsHasFooter fsHasOneColumnLayout fsSection334 fsHasTheme2 remove-district-home contrast-issue

li.a: Story Time with the Suit Guy
Bonds to Improve Safety, and Renovate and Construct Schools (April 2015)
Replacement of Expiring Levy for Educational Programs & Operations 2018

p.strong: This page will be updated as new information is available. Please continue to check back for updates.

li.a: HOW LONG WILL THE SCHOOL CLOSURE LAST?
WHAT ABOUT STUDENTS THAT NEED MEALS?
WILL EHS STILL HOLD PROM AND GRADUATION?
WHAT IF MY STUDENT(S) IS IN A SPORT OR ACTIVITY?
ARE STUDENTS GOING TO BE REQUIRED TO DO ONLINE LEARNING FROM HOME?
DO EHS STUDENTS HAVE TO DO ANY HOMEWORK WHILE AT HOME?
ARE STUDENTS ALLOWED ON CAMPUS DURING SCHOOL CLOSURE?
HOW CAN HIGH SCHOOL AND MIDDLE SCHOOL STUDENTS USE A CHROMEBOOK WHEN THEY DON’T HAVE INTERNET ACCESS?
IS PUBLIC HEALTH RECOMMENDING CANCELLATION OF COMMUNITY EVENTS OUTSIDE OF SCHOOL HOURS THAT INVOLVE FAMILY AS SPECTATORS OR PARTICIPANTS, LIKE SCHOOL SPORTS GAMES AND PTA MEETINGS?
WHAT SHOULD I/WE DO IF MY CHILD IS ILL?
HOW WILL THE INSTRUCTIONAL TIME BE MADE UP?
WHAT CAN I DO TO PROTECT MYSELF AND MY FAMILY AND PREVENT THE SPREAD OF COVID-19?
SHOULD I OR MY STUDENT WEAR A MASK?

h2.a: HOW LONG WILL THE SCHOOL CLOSURE LAST?

div.p: Per Governor Inslee, P-12 schools across our state will not return to a “brick and mortar” learning environment for the remainder of the 2019 - 2020 school year. Our plans for continuous learning will now continue through June 19, 2020.

h2.a: WHAT ABOUT STUDENTS THAT NEED MEALS?

div.p: We will be distributing these bags Monday - Friday from 11:00 - 12:30 at the following locations:

Enumclaw High School
226 Semanski Street S,
Enumclaw, WA 98022

Enumclaw Library
1700 1st St,
Enumclaw, WA 98022

Black Diamond Elementary
25314 Baker St,
Black Diamond, WA 98010

Westwood Elementary
21200 S.E. 416TH
Enumclaw, WA 98022

Byron Kibler Elementary
2057 Kibler Avenue
Enumclaw, WA 98022

Cedarbrook Mobile Home Park
31108 3rd Ave
Black Diamond, WA 98010
Cumberland Fire Station* between 11:00- 11:45 am
Selleck* (Across from the old Selleck school) between 11:45 - 12:30 pm
*Cumberland and Selleck will be delivered by bus so times may vary slightly

h2.a: WILL EHS STILL HOLD PROM AND GRADUATION?

div.p: As of now, all events that were scheduled for after April 27th will still take place.

h2.a: WHAT IF MY STUDENT(S) IS IN A SPORT OR ACTIVITY?

div.p: All practices, games, and events will be canceled while school is not in session.

h2.a: ARE STUDENTS GOING TO BE REQUIRED TO DO ONLINE LEARNING FROM HOME?

div.p: No. We will be providing you with learning opportunities online but you will not be required to complete new classwork through online learning.
The following was released by OSPI March 6, 2020, regarding distance and online learning:

blockquote.p: Many districts have requested additional guidance regarding the feasibility and legality of providing online learning in the event of an extended school closure. OSPI does not recommend closed schools transition to an online distance model unless the district can ensure each of the considerations below can be met.
These include, but are not limited to:
• Ensuring all students in the school or district will have equal access to the learning and required materials, including technology.

• Ensuring the online learning system can effectively support the district’s different learning and teaching needs, including the ability to provide differentiated instruction as well as one-on-one support for students who need it. Regardless of where the learning is happening, supports identified on a student’s Individualized Education Program (IEP) must be provided if the district is operating.
• Ensuring the requirements of full-day kindergarten are met.
• Ensuring students can access the assessments associated with dual credit coursework.
• Providing training to staff, students, and parents and guardians on how the system works and what expectations the district has.
• The ability to track the attendance of both students and staff.
• Ensuring the systems in use are secure and will not allow for the release of protected student or staff information.

• The ability to provide school meals. Taking a traditional school environment online is not a simple task – nor is it one that should be attempted without serious consideration of the practicality and risk.

p.b: At this time, ESD is not capable of ensuring ALL of these considerations can be met and will not be implementing an online distance model. We will continue to provide supplemental learning opportunities and will continue to explore and provide the best opportunities for all of our students.

h2.a: DO EHS STUDENTS HAVE TO DO ANY HOMEWORK WHILE AT HOME?

div.p: This is a great opportunity for students to finish work they may be behind on. We are going to provide learning opportunities while school is closed, which may look different for each of their classes.

h2.a: ARE STUDENTS ALLOWED ON CAMPUS DURING SCHOOL CLOSURE?

div.p: All schools are closed to public use at this time.

h2.a: HOW CAN HIGH SCHOOL AND MIDDLE SCHOOL STUDENTS USE A CHROMEBOOK WHEN THEY DON’T HAVE INTERNET ACCESS?

div.p:
Here is a video link/photo with instructions:
https://youtu.be/d8DECY7-0PQ

img.alt: How to login to your Chromebook when you don't have an internet connection.

div.h5: Ways to prepare for offline work:
div.p: Make sure you have “offline” turned on while you still have Wi-Fi access!

img.alt: Check 'Templates' - Display recent templates on home screens and click OK

ul.li: You will need your charger. A dead Chromebook won’t work offline or online!
You can start NEW Docs, Slides, Sheets or Drawings in offline mode from your Google Drive.
Once you have internet access again all your work will be in your Drive.

h2.a: IS PUBLIC HEALTH RECOMMENDING CANCELLATION OF COMMUNITY EVENTS OUTSIDE OF SCHOOL HOURS THAT INVOLVE FAMILY AS SPECTATORS OR PARTICIPANTS, LIKE SCHOOL SPORTS GAMES AND PTA MEETINGS?

div.p: Since adults are more at risk of serious illness from novel coronavirus, when possible, it’s a good idea for schools to practice social distancing by postponing unessential community events involving adults. In particular, we recommend that people over age 60, those with underlying health conditions like heart disease, lung disease, diabetes, or weakened immune systems stay home and away from large groups of people as much as possible. There is not much information about novel coronavirus in pregnancy, so we suggest pregnant women also take precautions recommended for other high-risk groups.
The Governor has prohibited gatherings of 250 or more and King County Public Health has put restrictions on gatherings of less than 250.

h2.a: WHAT SHOULD I/WE DO IF MY CHILD IS ILL?

div.p: Sick individuals should stay home and away from others and contact their healthcare provider if needed. The healthcare provider can assess the individual’s risk and determine whether they should be tested for novel coronavirus.

h2.a: HOW WILL THE INSTRUCTIONAL TIME BE MADE UP?

div.p: The ESD is working closely with Public Health Seattle and King County Health, OSPI, and partner agencies with regard to COVID-19. We are exploring all opportunities for waivers with OSPI, but may need to add the missed days to the end of the school year if we do not qualify for those waivers.

h2.a: WHAT CAN I DO TO PROTECT MYSELF AND MY FAMILY AND PREVENT THE SPREAD OF COVID-19?

div.p: Coronaviruses, including COVID-19, spread between people who are in close contact with one another (within about 6 feet) via coughing or sneezing. It may also spread by touching a surface or object with the virus on it. The same good health habits that prevent other viruses like the flu also prevent the spread of COVID-19 and decrease the risk of getting sick:

ul.li: Wash your hands often with soap and water for at least 20 seconds. Use an alcohol-based hand sanitizer, with 60% alcohol, if soap and water are not available.
Cough into a tissue or your elbow (not your hand), then throw tissue away and wash your hands.
Avoid touching your eyes, nose, or mouth with unwashed hands.
Avoid contact with people who are sick.
Stay home when you are sick.
Keep students home if they are running a temperature or they report not feeling well or appear weak or ill.
Consult your health care provider if you or your child has health conditions that put you at increased risk.

h2.a: SHOULD I OR MY STUDENT WEAR A MASK?

div.p: Public Health agencies currently do not recommend that people wear masks when they are in public. Additionally, scientists are not sure whether wearing a mask in public actually keeps healthy people from getting sick. It is more important for people who are sick to wear a mask in a healthcare setting (such as a waiting room) to avoid exposing other people when they cough or sneeze. As COVID-19 has spread, the supply of masks has been depleted, and it’s important to make masks available to those health care workers most directly working with the disease.

In some parts of the world, mask use when sick is customary. People also wear masks for a variety of reasons, including avoiding pollen and air pollution, as a courtesy to others when they have the common cold, and for other cultural and even social reasons. Please do not assume that someone wearing a mask has COVID-19.

This is a dynamic situation. For the most up-to-date information, visit the Public Health Seattle & King County website and sign up for email alerts from their agency. The District continues to follow the guidance of the U.S. Centers for Disease Control and Prevention (CDC) and Public Health Seattle & King County in our response to COVID-19, including decisions to close schools and whether students or staff would need to be quarantined.

Enumclaw School District will provide updates on any changes directed from King County Public Health. Updates will be communicated below and via email. Please ensure that email contact information is up-to-date on your Family Access Account in Skyward at http://eaplus.enumclaw.wa-k12.net/. Please contact Jamie Franz at 360-802-7121 if you are having difficulty updating your information.
For the most up-to-date information, visit the Public Health Seattle & King County website and sign up for email alerts from their agency.
What resources are available for talking to kids about COVID-19?

ul.li: Here’s an informative graphic resource from NPR.
Guidance from the National Child Traumatic Stress Network on talking to kids in a way that will reduce stress and help calm anxieties.
Tips from the Washington State Department of Health for teaching proper handwashing techniques.

img.alt: District logo with white bottom font

div.div:
Enumclaw School District 2929 McDougall Ave.
Enumclaw, WA 98022
Contact Us
